statement.text: Mesenteric ischemia carries among the highest mortality rates of any surgical emergency, with acute arterial occlusion reaching 50-80% in-hospital mortality despite treatment, primarily due to delayed diagnosis, and chronic disease carrying 5-10% operative mortality with excellent long-term survival after successful revascularization.
statement.formal: Mortality Spectrum: AMI arterial (50-80%) > NOMI (70-90%) > MVT (20-50%) >> CMI elective (5-10%)

explanation.intuition: Mesenteric ischemia mortality is a race between disease progression and intervention. Acute disease kills quickly because the bowel dies in hours, diagnosis is often delayed, and patients are typically elderly with significant comorbidities. Chronic disease allows time for diagnosis and planned intervention, explaining the dramatic mortality difference.
explanation.key_insight: The high mortality in AMI is predominantly driven by delay - delay in considering the diagnosis, delay in obtaining imaging, and delay in reaching the operating room. Studies consistently show that time from symptom onset to revascularization is the strongest predictor of survival. This is a disease where hours matter.

nonocclusive_mesenteric_ischemia.reason_for_highest: Occurs in critically ill, delayed diagnosis, limited treatment options

mesenteric_venous_thrombosis.reason_for_lower: More indolent course, responds to anticoagulation

chronic_mesenteric_ischemia.reason_for_best: Elective, planned intervention, no acute bowel threat

disease_factors.bowel_necrosis: Present vs absent is strongest predictor
disease_factors.etiology: NOMI and thrombosis worse than embolism

metabolic_factors.organ_failure: Each additional organ failure increases mortality

long_term_survivors.patency: Depends on revascularization method (see treatment AKUs)
long_term_survivors.quality_of_life: Generally good if avoid extensive resection

prognostic_models.existing_scores: No widely validated specific score for AMI

sources.citation: National database studies on mesenteric ischemia

learning_objectives: Understand the mortality spectrum across mesenteric ischemia types
Appreciate the time-critical nature of AMI
Counsel patients and families on expected outcomes
clinical_pearls: The #1 predictor of death is bowel necrosis - prevent it with early diagnosis
Hours matter - treat AMI like stroke or STEMI
NOMI is the silent killer with worst prognosis
CMI treated electively has excellent outcomes
